headline: Turkey Brine
description: Use this turkey brine recipe to produce an easy, flavorful main dish this Thanksgiving. All you need is vegetable broth, herbs, and a big food-safe bucket.

video.description: This brine infuses your bird with flavor and makes it moist.
video.name: Turkey Brine

name: Turkey Brine

recipeInstructions.text: Combine vegetable broth, sea salt, rosemary, sage, thyme, and savory in a large stock pot. Bring to a boil, stirring frequently to be sure salt is dissolved. Remove from heat, and let cool to room temperature.
When the broth mixture is cool, pour it into a clean 5-gallon bucket. Stir in the ice water.

Rinse and dry your turkey. Make sure you have removed the innards. Place the turkey, breast down, into the brine. Make sure that the cavity gets filled. Place the bucket in the refrigerator for 8 hours, or overnight.
Remove the turkey carefully, draining off the excess brine and pat dry. Discard excess brine.
Cook the turkey as desired reserving the drippings for gravy. Keep in mind that brined turkeys cook 20 to 30 minutes faster so watch the temperature gauge.

review.reviewBody: I have been using this brine for the last 3 years for Thanksgiving. I'm currently using it for a chicken. It is easy to make and use. Thank you for sharing it.
Using it for years tried a different one this year never again have to come back this one is just so yummy
I add a quart of apple juice, but all the rest the same. It is the best!
Brined it for two days got a lot of compliments on it

I brined for 36 hours using a 20 Lb farm raised turkey. It made a perfect turkey and prevented it from being too dry even after the white meat reached around 190 degrees. (Even at 325, the turkey cooked half an hour faster than it was supposed to.) I followed the brine recipe as closely as I could. I used a mix of broths, because that's what I had. Adding half a cup of brown sugar didn't change the brine much. However, I had to make my own savory, and savory recipes vary. This particular savory recipe had cloves and allspice and not enough garlic. The leftovers and the soup had a hint of clove and allspice flavor, as a result. However, everyone loved the turkey, and they absolutely raved about the gravy, so I give this recipe a five star rating.

Brined for 30 hours using an 18 lb Butterball turkey, turned out juicy and flavorful. Was worried it may be too salty but the brine is mainly to tenderize the meat and is washed off. Buttered the turkey, including under skin before roasting.

I have now used this recipe foe the last 5 years. Consistently this bird steels the show. I completely thaw my turkey and brine for 24 hours. I follow exactly as posted but have found that putting the turkey in a turkey bag (there is always 2 in a box- use the second one for cooking the bird) with the brine and squeeze out the air and close with the tie works really well. Placing the bag in the deep turkey pan also makes it easy to store in the fridge. For baking the turkey, pat dry turkey lightly and rub with butter. In the second bag, put 1/4 c flour and shake bag, place turkey breast side down. Put several stocks of celery chopped and one large onion, peeled and sliced in bag. Close up and seal with tie. Put a few cuts in the bag and a meat thermometer. An 18 pound turkey took 2h30min at 350 degrees.
Everyone loves when I use this recipe at Thanksgiving!

I like this is a base. I changed it up a bit because I smoked 1 of my birds. I added 1/2 cup dark brown sugar and 1/4 cup of shire sauce and added peels from 2 additional oranges. After the brine process I used a rib rub and butter mixture to rub underneath the skin and dusted the outside with my rub. I smoked with Pecan at 225 Turned out great! very juicy and tons of flavor
Super easy and honestly the best brine I have ever made. Every year I am showered with compliments because the Turkey always turns out so moist and juicy. This is my go-to Brine!
I've been using this brine for years now. Whether I bake or smoke the turkey, it comes out super moist and tasty.

I took over Thanksgiving about 8 yrs ago. I’ve never been impressed with my birds. Last year was the first time I brined the bird. Holy cow! It was the best bird I’ve ever cooked! I’m back for a second year with high hopes for the same results. I could not find Savory last year, but I’m on the hunt for it this year. I use a brining bag in a cooler and leave it on my deck overnight, 12+ hours. I do not stuff the bird. Last year I had a 17lb bird - cooked at 350, placed tin foil over the breast for the first 2 hrs and I did not baste at all. It reached 165 degrees in 2.5 hours.
Super tasty and juicy.
This was a big hit for my family. I didn’t have savoury but it was still very flavourful and juicy.

This is an excellent brine. I've used it when smoking or baking my turkeys. For an extra flavor add three fresh oranges and lemons to the brine. Yes I love experimenting and my family loved the hint of citrus to the smoked turkey.

This past Thanksgiving I brined a turkey for the first time using this recipe. Never in my life have I ever had such a juicy turkey that cut with a fork. I would highly recommend this recipe if you want to make sure your turkey tastes delicious!
Turned out great!

Well, I guess everything turned out ok, but... 

I put the almost 21# bird in our Jenn-Air convection oven at 1 PM. At 3:17 I checked the thigh and it was 172 degrees. I freaked thinking I overcooked it! Took it out, and the cavity had 2 cups of pink fluid in the cavity (Thank God I didn't stuff it!). I sucked out the fluid and put it back in for an hour. Still, whatever liquid was left never dried out and it was still pink. And yes, it was completely thawed! 

I ended up taking it out and carving it in the kitchen, leaving the cavity untouched as best I could. The meat was OK, but definitely not as moist as it could have been.

Best Turkey I ever made. Meat was tender and juicy. What a wonderful bird! I will use this recipe the rest of my life. No more questioning recipes and trying new things. Perfection doesn’t need to be changed! ??
Great brine but added apple cider. Thought I’d add a tip: ice bags are food grade so I brine it in the bag and throw the ice in a clean cooler. Stays cold and no garbage bag contaminates.

Definitely the most flavorful turkey I have ever cooked. Moistest turkey ever and it is easy to prepare. I had to order Ground Savory from Amazon because it is very difficult to find, every store was out if it. It was well worth the effort.
Not a leftover yet
Excellent brine. I used kosher salt instead of sea salt.
Have used this brine for over 5 years in a row. My family raves every year that it's the most delicious and tender turkey ever.

This recipe changed my life! I made it years ago and my mother-in-law handed the Thanksgiving turkey responsible to me from that point forward because it was so good. I did reduce the salt like many people in the reviews suggested.
Thank you.

I have used this brine recipe for the last 17 years. It never fails! Turkey comes out moist and delicious. Make write you rinse the turkey off inside and out before you stuff it it else the gravy will have a sea salt taste to it. Also subtract a half an hour off the cooking time. I leave my Turkey in the brine for about 30 hours. You won’t be disappointed.
Never ever go without brining a turkey again.

What a great and simple recipe that gives amazing results! Didn't have savory but fixed verbatim otherwise, brined a turkey for 2 days in the fridge and the turkey turned out spectacular. It dawned on me after setting it to brine that I should've reduced the salt for a frozen turkey, but it didn't turn out salty. I even made this entirely with generic brand ingredients and everyone raved about how good it was. Thanks for sharing this one, it's definitely a keeper!

I received high compliments. Someone who does not care for turkey said it was the best they’d ever tasted. Very moist. Note: I brined it for 5 days vs one day and I added unsweetened cranberry juice and a touch of unsweetened jam.

I would recommend this to anybody it was delicious. The white meat was very juicy and the only change that I made was I did not have any savory so I used a tablespoon of old Bay seasoning and it was fantastic!!

Made it, but used “poultry seasoning” instead of buying the individual seasonings because of budget constraints. The turkey came out AMAZING and I will be using the recipe any time I have to make a bird.

Made it!! loved it!! 
can’t wait to do it again!!
I have brined before but this was an easy recipe. I used kosher salt but It was a bit salty. But my kosher salt a little fine that could’ve contributed to the taste

You can customize this for your needs and what’s available. It really made a delicious turkey. I also added cut up celery and apples and used those to stuff the turkey while it cooked-came out very moist.

This is the first time I have ever brined a turkey. This brine was so easy and made my turkey juicy and delicious. After reading comments, I chose to rinse the turkey after brining. I also buttered the whole turkey, and inserted butter and fresh herbs under the breast skin. I will definitely use this again.

Roasted my first turkey this year and this simple brine helped make it a huge hit for my quarantine Friendsgiving! So much flavor and easy enough that I'll definitely be doing it again for future occasions. For a 12.5lb bird, I used about half as much vegetable broth and water but kept the herb measurements the same. Also, because I used a frozen butterball (they're injected with a saline solution that I hadn't known about before purchasing) only 1/2 cup of salt and low sodium broth was used which kept it from getting too salty. I did add some bay leaves and minced garlic since we didn't have any savory on hand which rounded out the flavor nicely. If you're using freezer bags for the actual brining process, I would recommend double bagging it. Our turkey + brine was able to fit in an extra large (2.5 gallon) ziplock but the first bag sprung a leak that could have been a disaster if it hadn't been discovered early on. Double bagging it and putting it in a baking pan kept it safely in place as it sat in the fridge overnight.
It was the best I have made
Yes...great brine. Very moist...I didn’t have savory so just upped the other spices by 1teaspoon.
Excellent! I followed the recipe, only reduced the salt to 1 cup - I only had a 10 pound Turkey so that seemed enough. It was great! Juicy turkey!
I used this brine this year and everyone said it was the best turkey they have ever had .
This turkey brine turned out great! Turkey was juicy and flavorful. I didn't have any "savory" available, but used poultry spices instead. Will use this brine even with chicken.
My favorite brine

This brine converted some turkey deniars anti turkey believers. It made our turkey soon tasty. We brined a 10lbs turkey for two days, and the salt and herb flavor penetrated all the way through. The only thing I would change is the amount of salt for smaller turkey - a cup is a bit too much. It made a very salty gravy.

The BEST turkey I ever cooked! I used 2 quarts chicken stock 2 q vegetable stock, kosher salt and several sprigs of fresh rosemary. Fabulous, moist and flavorful. I never write reviews but this rocks!

Best turkey I've ever had. I did use the 1 gallon of apple juice rather than the ice water, suggested by one reviewer. I just stuck the gallon in the freezer while making the brine. Came out great. Hubby and kids loved it.
Amazing !! This produced the JUICIEST and tender turkey. It was like slicing butter .

If I could give this a million stars I would do it!! So glad I heard about brining and wish I would have heard about it sooner! I doubled the recipe and used 1 gallon of vegetable juice and 1 gallon of apple juice. I didn’t have the savory because I couldn’t find it. I let it brine for almost 24 hours. When I took it out I dried it then put it in the fridge. My son decided to try something he saw on TikTok and put butter under the skin. These two things made for the juiciest and most flavorful turkey, EVER!! To top it all off, my 20 lb turkey was fully cooked in 2 hours!!! I will never go back to the old way of roasting a turkey!
I’ve made this recipe every year for the last 11 years. It’s always juicy and always a hit! Juicy, flavorful and simple!
Go to every year. Add a gallon of apple juice to make a 20pound bird. Super juicy.
Great recipe!

I have been using this recipe every year Thanksgiving and a few other special occasions too. Only substitutions I have made are to use Turkey Broth instead of Vegetable Broth and occasionally will add a different spice depending on time of year.

A game changer.... instead of being a dry and obligatory part of Thanksgiving and Christmas dinners, my family now requests turkey. It's easy, so long as you think ahead and get the bird thawed. Thanks for the recipe.

I’ve made this brine probably 5 times and the only thing I don’t use is the savory. I may be missing out on something but even with that omitted it makes the most tender juicy bird I’ve ever had! I didn’t have a large refrigerator so I opted for using a cooler. I put my turkey in a turkey roasting bag, placed it in the cooler, added the brine, tied up the bag tight add ice all around and close the lid for at least 24 hours. After rinsing, slather the bird with cold butter and pepper. Add some onion, celery, half of an orange and half an apple inside the bird and the magic starts. Definitely check temps because of it cooking faster than your average turkey. Yummy!
Used Turkey Stock instead of vegetable stack.
I’ve been using this recipe for years. Have even tried it without the broth and it’s still great.

Everyone has loved this brine and it is simple and easy to adjust. The flavor is great complement to however I season, cook and serve poultry. For chicken most of the brine effect and flavor is finished in 30 minutes.
I use this every thanksgiving!
I only had time for my turkey to brine for four hours. I then cooked it in a turkey bag and the results were amazing, very moist and tender.

I've been using this recipe for over 5 years. 
the turkey is super tender each time. Love it!
moist and juicy !!
I made this as the first time brining a turkey. I followed the instructions but it turned out way too salty.
Awesome
Made no changes except that I only soaked turkey for about 12 hours. Made a delicious turkey and I will definitely do this from now on.
This was exceptional both times I used it. The turkey was moist and FULL of flavor! The drippings made for a gravy that was as good as Mom's.
I’ve used this recipe twice and love it, there’s no other way! Always a a very moist and flavorful turkey and the gravy doesn’t even need seasoning. Excellent!
This is my first turkey brine and it turned out sooooo good! Thank you for making my Thanksgiving awesome!

This was my first time EVER making a turkey. I scoured the internet for brining recipes and most of called for either brown sugar or apple juice. I don’t care for sweet meat, I prefer savory, so I was super excited to find this recipe. I read the reviews and followed several tips. 

First off, my turkey was 23 lbs. I used fresh herbs (excluding savory as I had no idea what that was). I used the entire gallon of veggie broth, but cut the salt back to 3/4 cup. I added in 2 largely chopped sweet onions, peppercorns, 9 cloves of garlic, and the gallon of ice water. I let the turkey marinate in a large bucket I’m the fridge for 24 hours.

To cook it, I preheated the oven to 325 degrees, started the turkey off breast down. After two hours, I flipped the turkey and cooked for another hour. By then it had reached an internal temp of 180 degrees (it only needs to be 165, but the turkey was still super juicy even with slightly over cooking). I then cranked up the heat to 400 degrees, basted the turkey with butter, and cooked another 15 minutes. It turned out perfectly Golden. The turkey was so flavorful and moist!! I’m not a turkey fan, but this was delicious!! My entire family loved it, including my super picky eaters!! 

This recipe is an absolute repeat!!! I might even try it on chicken for regular weeknight dinners. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!

This is the best brine recipe we have ever used. We use a 5 gallon brine bucket for our 24 lb turkey. We make sure the cavity of the turkey is filled and the breast meat is well covered because not all of the liquid fits. We have used the recipe now for 3 years and the turkey is never dried out and the meat is extremely flavorful.
I’ve made this a few times now and the family loves it. It works great as is, but I’ve also added a whole lemon and two tablespoons of whole peppercorns to the brine.

Have been making this brine for years! I love it! Juiciest yummiest turkey ever. Will never not brine my turkey! The only thing I do different is add sliced oranges to the brine, otherwise it by itself is still amazing!
This is a great recipe! I’ve been using this one to brine for several years now!
One change - I used Kosher salt because that is what i had in the house - and chicken broth because I could not find the vegetable broth
I cut the recipe in half for a Turkey breast. I also added 1 Tbsp. Onion powder, 1 tsp. Garlic powder and 1 tsp. Black pepper to the half. Recipe.
I used this last year for Thanksgiving and the turkey turned out juicy and delicious! Using again this year!
Always perfect...

This is a great recipe as the proportions are correct. So, I start here every year. Most Helpful hint: For the salt, 1 cup of sea salt (or table salt) is equal to 1 1/4 cups of Morten's Kosher OR 3/4 cup of Diamond Crystal Kosher. In addition to the stated herbs, I add a T of Whole Peppercorns and a T of Allspice Berries. Sometimes I swap out 3 times the herbs fresh instead of dried. 2019 version also had some leek tops and parsley stems. Basically, use up those trimmed vege bits and throw them into the brine pot too :)

My husband and I use this recipe for brining smoked turkey breast. We brine the 8 to 10 pound breast for about 8 hours in a bowl in the refrigerator. Then he puts it on the grill to smoke. Sometimes he uses fruits tree chips to increase the smoke flavor. Our family raves! They are moist and flavorful. Everything a turkey breast should be!

Have used this recipe for the past few years. We did a taste test last year and made one turkey unbrined and the other brined and the brined turkey was the clear winner. I recommend and use the suggestion to add 1/2 gallon of apple juice. 5 stars.
This is my go-to brine for Thanksgiving turkey. Say goodbye to a dry bird. This brine produces a moist, juicy, and flavorful turkey.

Delicious, but adjust the salt. Used on a 12-pound turkey, placed in a scrubbed-out cooler overnight. Even after rinsing the brine prior to cooking, the meat was quite salty, although delicious and juicy. Will try again for the actual holiday using either no salt, or getting low-sodium broth. The comment about cooking faster held true: I used a baking bag for the turkey, and rubbed the skin with butter prior to placing in the bag. The turkey registered 300 degrees after 2.5 hours, so my guess is a 12-pound, brined turkey actually takes about 2 hours when using a bag to cook.
I use turkey sized oven bags to brine my turkey. You can store in the refrigerator easier during brining.
We use this recipe every year at Thanksgiving and Christmas.
Used this brine last year and so excited to use it again for Thanksgiving! Thank you for a wonderful recipe!
Best turkey brine recipe! The tip on adding apple juice to the brine took this to another level. Turned out amazing!
I made no changes, my family did not like this turkey. We all thought there was a weird after taste with this brine and will never use again.
This is a wonderful brine. I have made this many many holidays always with perfect results. It is very important to use a food grade container or bag.

I have made roasted turkeys, deep fried turkeys, and my favorite, smoked turkeys. There are endless ways for a turkey to be prepared.
With that said, this brine will be one more addition to my turkey arsenal.
This time I oven roasted it, but I'm thinking next time I might try a little apple smoke...

If you cook the bird right, this brine is perfect. Savory and juicy results. I have had trouble finding the perfect amount of brine. The grocery store either has containers that have way too much or too little in too many cans.

Have been using this for a few years. Perfectly delicious moist turkey every time. I always buy the cheap store variety of turkey and this makes the best! The first lesson I learned was sea salt is NOT table salt. Really good!
Made it last 4 Thanksgivings. Didn't change a thing. Delicious.

I’ve used this recipe twice so far. Once on a really expensive turkey from the butcher shop and once on a cheap generic turkey on clearance after the holiday. In both cases the turkey came out amazing and extremely well flavored and moist. Now I will brine my turkey’s with this recipe every time.
I never brined my turkeys in the past. Why? I'm not sure. It works and makes a huge difference. This recipe is really good. Just do it. Everyone thinks you're a genius in the kitchen.

This is the best brine ever! The first time I made the turkey for my extended family, our usual carver for the family bird said that he had never seen the meat so tender and juicy. The meat fell off of the bone. I quickly became the turkey cook for the Thanksgiving Day celebration. I've been using this recipe for T-day and X-mas for a couple of years and everyone loves it! The meat is juicy and flavorful!
Best turkey I’ve ever made

My first time using a brine! I did not find savory spice , but with the other ingredients and the addition of marjoram, the turkey turned out moist and delicious! Will definitely be using this recipe next time!
Love this
perfect brine!
I did this for the first time last Christmas and it was by far the best Turkey we have ever cooked. It was super moist and so flavourful. Will be doing this as a standard for the foreseeable future!

This was fantastic! This turkey squirts when you slice it, that’s how juicy it is. I use a thermometer and don’t overlook it and let it rest at least 30 min. Super flavorful.i have made this the last 5 years and my husband says no other turkey is as good as yours! ( this one )
